data Directory #

An open directory handle. Composes Ext2.Directory and Handle

data DirEntry #

A directory entry. Associates a node with the name given it by its parent directory.

openDirAsP #

Arguments

:: User

The user whose permissions will be used when opening the directory.

-> Path

A path which names a directory.

-> OpenMode

The directory open mode (read/write).

-> FS Directory

The opened directory in FS.

Open a directory as a given user.

closeDir :: Directory -> FS () #

Close a directory.

readDir :: Directory -> FS DirEntry #

Read the next directory entry from a directory. It is an error to attempt to read more than the number of entries in the directory, which can be checked with getDirSize.

mapDir :: (DirEntry -> FS a) -> Directory -> FS [a] #

Map a function over all the entries in a directory. NB: The reading position is not altered (unless the function argument to mapDir causes it) so thatthe code: entry1 <- readDir dir mapDir f dir entry2 <- readDir Has the same effect as if mapDir was removed, i.e. entry1 and entry2 are adjacent entries.

getDirHandle :: Directory -> FS Handle #

Get the handle associated with a directory.

readDirToEnd :: Directory -> FS [DirEntry] #

Read all the entries of a directory into a list.

getDirSize :: Directory -> FS (Maybe Int) #

Get the number of entries in a directory.

data Filesystem #

Filesystem.

Constructors

NotMounted

An invalid/unmounted filesystem. | A mounted filesystem.

    Ext2 volume.

  • handles :: [Maybe HandleInfo]

    List of handles.

    The root directory.

Instances

Show Filesystem # 

Methods

showsPrec :: Int -> Filesystem -> ShowS #

show :: Filesystem -> String #

showList :: [Filesystem] -> ShowS #

type FS a = State Filesystem a #

FS monad.

get :: Monad m => StateT s m s #

Fetch the current value of the state within the monad.

put :: Monad m => s -> StateT s m () #

put s sets the state within the monad to s.

sync :: FS a -> Filesystem -> IO a #

Apply a filesystem action to a mounted filesystem and return the result in IO. Due to lazy evaluation, filesystem operations are not evaluated until sync is called.

appendFDHandleInfo :: HandleInfo -> FS Int #

Append the HandleInfo for a newly opened handle to a filesystem's list of open handles and get a file descriptor unique to it. It is NOT an error if there is already a handle to the same node, though it may cause strange behaviour.

updateFDHandleInfo :: Int -> (Maybe HandleInfo -> Maybe HandleInfo) -> FS (Maybe HandleInfo) #

Update the HandleInfo referenced by a file descriptor by applying a function to it and return the result. It is an error if the file descriptor refers to a closed or otherwise invalid handle.

isInUse :: FS Bool #

Indicates whether the filesystem is in use, i.e. if there are open handles.

getStatistics :: FS String #

Get printable statistics about the filesystem.

openHandles :: Filesystem -> [HandleInfo] #

Get a list of currently open handles.

getFDHandleInfo :: Int -> FS (Maybe HandleInfo) #

Get the HandleInfo referenced by a file descriptor. If the handle is closed, the result will be Nothing.

haveFDHandleInfo :: Int -> FS Bool #

Indicates whether a file descriptor is associated with an open handle.

maybeHI :: a -> (HandleInfo -> FS a) -> Int -> FS a #

Helper for functions which execute conditionally on whether a handle is opened.

data Handle #

A Filesystem handle - references an open file or directory within the filesystem. Essentially equivalent to POSIX - file descriptors (in fact it is exactly equal).

Instances

Eq Handle # 

Methods

(==) :: Handle -> Handle -> Bool #

(/=) :: Handle -> Handle -> Bool #

Show Handle # 

Methods

showsPrec :: Int -> Handle -> ShowS #

show :: Handle -> String #

showList :: [Handle] -> ShowS #

openH #

Arguments

:: User

Use the permissions of a user to open the file.

-> Node

The node to which the handle should refer.

-> OpenMode

The opening mode.

-> FS Handle

An open handle to the node wrapped in updated FS.

Open a handle to a filesystem node.

openHWithSize :: User -> Node -> OpenMode -> Int -> FS Handle #

Open a handle, overriding the size reported by the node. This is a workaround to allow directories to report their size as the number of entries they contain, rather than the sum of the sizes of the entries.

closeH :: Handle -> FS () #

Close a handle.

seekH :: Seek -> Int -> Handle -> FS () #

Update the read/write position of a handle.

readH :: Handle -> Int -> FS ByteString #

Read data from a handle.

isHOpen :: Handle -> FS Bool #

Indicates whether the handle is open.

isHClosed :: Handle -> FS Bool #

Indicates whether the handle is closed.

getHInfo :: Handle -> FS (Maybe HandleInfo) #

Get the HandleInfo associated with a Handle. If the handle is closed, Nothing is returned.

getHType :: Handle -> FS (Maybe NodeType) #

Get the NodeType associated with a Handle. If the handle is closed, Nothing is returned.

getHNode :: Handle -> FS (Maybe Node) #

Get the Node associated with a Handle. If the handle is closed, Nothing is returned.

getHOpenMode :: Handle -> FS (Maybe OpenMode) #

Get the OpenMode associated with a Handle. If the handle is closed, Nothing is returned.

getHPermissions :: Handle -> FS (Maybe Permission) #

Get the Permission associated with a Handle. If the handle is closed, Nothing is returned.

getHPosition :: Handle -> FS (Maybe Int) #

Get the position associated with a Handle. If the handle is closed, Nothing is returned.

getHSize :: Handle -> FS (Maybe Int) #

Get the size associated with a Handle. If the handle is closed, Nothing is returned.

data HandleInfo #

Describes an open or directory.

Constructors

HandleInfo 

Fields

  • hNode :: Node

    The filesystem node.

  • hType :: NodeType

    The node type.

  • hOpenMode :: OpenMode

    The opening mode.

  • hPermissions :: Permission

    The permissions of the handle.

  • hPosition :: Int

    The read/write position.

  • hSize :: Int

    The size of the file/directory in bytes.

makeHandleInfo :: User -> Node -> OpenMode -> HandleInfo #

Create and populate a HandleInfo record. Also performs permissions checks.

mount #

Arguments

:: String

A path to the file or device *in the *host* FS* which contains a filesystem.

-> IO Filesystem

The filesystem within IO. Use sync to use the filesystem in FS.

Mount a filesystem.

unmount :: FS () #

Unmount a filesystem. The unmount will fail if there are open handles.

forceUnmount :: FS () #

Unmount a filesystem forcibly. Invalidates all open handles.

withMount :: String -> FS a -> IO a #

Mount a filesystem and apply a filesystem action to it, returning the result in IO.

data NodeType #

Constructors

FileNode

A regular file.

DirNode

A directory. Contains references to other nodes.

SpecialNode

A special node such as a device or symbolic link.

data OpenMode #

File open mode.

Constructors

ReadOnly

Allow reading only.

WriteOnly

Allow writing only.

ReadWrite

Allow reading and writing.

Append

Allow writing at the end of the file only.

Show Permission # 

Methods

showsPrec :: Int -> Permission -> ShowS #

show :: Permission -> String #

showList :: [Permission] -> ShowS #

getPermissions :: User -> Node -> Permission #

Get permissions of a node wrt a given user. In other words, tests whether a user is allowed to read, write and - execute a node and wraps this in a Permission.

isCurPos :: Seek -> Bool #

Indicates whether to seek from the current position.

computeSeek #

Arguments

:: Integral a 
=> Seek

The seek type

-> (a, a, a)

The seek boundaries in form (minimum,current,maximum)

-> a

The proposed seek offset. For example 1 if seeking by 1 byte.

-> a

The absolute position to seek to.

Computes a new seek position bounded by the minimum, current and maximum values.
